reviewText: The story centers around 2 people that fall in love and their dysfunctional family lives. Matthew, a gifted 30 something computer engineer and Maria, a spoiled naive teenager. Maria's boyfriend ends up getting her pregnant and not wanting anything to do with her, she drops out of school, her mother is controlling, her fathers dead and shes basically hit rock bottom. Matthew has similiar problems with his father. His fathers abusive and Matthew has somewhat of a suicial streak. During all this, These two end up stumbling upon eachother and eventually falling in love...though its not your typical courtship. Its more of a reluctant meeting of the minds. 2 misfits who just happened to come across eachother at the perfect time. They soon learn a lot about eachother while confronting their inner demons and issues while 'changing' eachother for the better.What makes the film good is not so much the plot but the interaction between the characters. It shares a similar theme/humor with the Todd Solondz movie 'Happiness', except this one has a more serious vibe about it... Serious yet humorous. Its one of those movies you really can't categorize. It's hard to explain in words what makes this movie so good, you just have to watch it. Definitely worth the watch.. different, original & heavy on the irony and dry humor. Highly Recommended.
Title: N/A

reviewText: My God! I can't begin to tell you how much I loved this movie!!This has to be one of the most original and thoughtful semi-serious-funny-romantic/non-romantic movie I've ever seen and it stands out in it's originality and feel to anything that I can recall that came before it and after it.Hollywood sure doesn't have what it takes to release a movie such as this anymore.  This was the first movie I became aquainted or rather introduced to both Martin Donovan and Ms. Shelley and Donovan's portrayal of the aptly named "Matthew Slaughter" has stuck in my mind ever since I first saw this movie. Yeah I was happy to finally see him again in movies such as "Pipe Dream" and most recently "Saved!" but Matthew Slaughter has lived on in my imagination now for God knows how long.Can't help it, whenever I think of Martin Donvoan, I got to think of Matthew, plus Adrienne Shelley's "Maria" is another of the standout characters that has affected me.Love the film, love the soundtrack, and you wouldn't believe how long I've searched both far and wide on the net to try to find the music to this film, but it's next as impossible to finding the actual film itself.Why in God's name is this movie released only for a region 4 and not able to be viewed here in the US?  Who the hell makes these decisions anyway?  Don't they know this film is loved and respected greatly here in America?  As for me I have no proof ofcourse but I chalk things like this up to Anti-American bias.  That's got to be the reason why these things just do not show up here and yet get released around the rest of the world.Please put a stop to this madness and release the movie HERE! in America! and stop screwing around please if you will.  Geez! Too much is too much. I get the message already, stop withholding from us!Peace, everyone.
summary: TRUST is what it's all about!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Hal Hartley's realistic love story between Michael Donovan (Wonderland) and Adrienne Lynne is hilarious. The two characters, one too smart to get a minimum wage job but too poor to make anything of himself because he has no  spirit and the other a girl whose father dies when she tells him she's  pregnant are looking for a reason to exist. The odd way Hal brings them  together and the quircky but very true things they say reveal how much  trust they develop in each other as the story progresses.  Keep a look out  for his father and her mother; they brighten the film with their hateful  ways. And the sarcasm abounds but look for illogical behavior because it  all makes sense in the end. If you liked Clerks, Chasing Amy, or  Quentinesque moving films, you'll like this one! Or if you're burned out on  sappy love stories and want to know can true love exist... watch Trust! You  will believe.
summary: The Quirkest, but most realistic love story
Title: N/A

reviewText: Strange but interesting saga of a young high school girl (played by Adrienne Shelly), who at the beginning of the movie is pregnant. She leaves home after having a falling out with her father, encounters the disheartened Rachel (who may be a babynapper), and then meets Matthew (Martin Donovan), a mechanical genius who can't stand the shoddy workmanship in today's products and who carries a hand grenade with him just in case he wants to commit suicide. They help each other out, especially regarding their sadistic parents, and decide to get married - which doesn't quite work out, thanks to her plotting mother and her deciding to have an abortion anyway.The tone and presentation of the characters and their actions are very unemotional and deadpan - sort of like RAISING ARIZONA, but without the comic punch. In fact, everything in the movie is so aloof and detached that we almost begin to think the director (Hal Hartley) doesn't care what the audience thinks: it's as if he can't be bothered to have his actors make their points meaningful. It distances us too much from the characters: if they don't care, why should we? Despite this take-it-or-leave-it attitude, there is some sharp dialogue throughout the proceedings. But the movie feels confined by an emotional straightjacket that it just can't break out of.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Trust" is the story of a pregnant high school girl (Maria, played by Adrienne Shelly) who reveals this fact to her parents one night.  In the ensuing drama she slaps her father and leaves, whereupon he falls to the ground, dead of a heart attack.  (At least four other characters faint dead away during the film too, though not as dead away as dear old Dad.)  The girl thinks her jock boyfriend will marry her.  Way wrong.Jilted, dazed, told by her mother to not come home, Maria begs at a bus stop for five bucks to buy some beer and the lady who loans her money kidnaps a baby left nearby by another idiot teen mom who leaves her baby on the street unattended.  Meanwhile Maria is being pawed in the back room by the store owner, who won't let her have her beer without a little flesh trade.The shop owner isn't the only moment where we wonder who's minding the store in this gaunt film where the parents are sadists, the children jaded beyond their years, and the occasional humor dished out with a heavy dose of bitterness.  There are some laugh-out-loud moments, but don't make the mistake of thinking "Trust" is a comedy.  "Black comedy" generally means that the filmmaker sees the humor in the worst of situations, and this film is full of the worst of situations.  Its low-budget look is as much a character as any of the speaking parts.Matthew (Martin Donovan) is the other lead in this unconventional romance, and the only thing in the world he's afraid of is his father.  Matthew has been so brutally abused for so long that everyone else cringes when he comes around, because he's basically the personification of the hand grenade he carries around; no one dares get anywhere near his pin.There are some screamingly false moments in "Trust," a film that seems to be all about gritty reality.  The scene where Maria asks her sister and a friend about their experience with motherhood and marriage, for example, is shot with Maria off camera, in interview style, as if the film had suddenly turned into a documentary.  The aforementioned shop owner in real life would certainly not leave his till and merchandise unwatched for several minutes with a disreputable-looking youngster in the store, even for a quickie with the tempting Maria.  The dialogue frequently sounds like all of the players are doing their best deadpan Bogart imitation, romance done film noir style, too often sounding less like individual people than actors spouting the words of a single author who's riffing on one subject or another and using two or more mouths to do the riffing.  In fact, the scene at the bus stop sports the very worst kind of self-conscious dialogue where two characters are actually carrying on separate monologues, like an outtake from a bad French film.  And I haven't seen four people faint in my entire life, but saw it in the span of less than two hours here.Fortunately, these moments are few and far between, and they ultimately amount to only minor distractions.  "Trust" is far more often a gripping character study with unfortunate souls who are almost too tough to feel much for, yet in those moments where they let their guard down we cheer.  For instance, a nurse in an abortion clinic pours this high school student a shot of straight whiskey (yeah, that'd happen) in a scene that is quickly rescued by a brilliant monologue for Maria, as she maturely discovers that her self-imposed role of eye candy isn't everything it's cracked up to be.Everyone should support a film that manages to move forward an unusual story while managing to develop the characters into something other than cardboard cutouts whose sole purpose is to advance the action.  "Trust" definitely hits its mark in this difficult balance, and in spite of its awkwardness it ends on an upbeat note that's surprisingly downbeat.  This story could not have ended any other way.  It's a remarkable film, one you won't soon forget.

reviewerName: Chris "the most passionate music/film fan alive."
reviewText: So finally, FINALLY.... Trust comes to DVD and it is a Region 1, USA/NTSC release. Years and years ago, I bought Trust directly from Hal Hartley's production company, and it is a region 4, PAL-format DVD (made for Australia). Thankfully I have a region-free NTSC/PAL DVD player, or else I would have been quite disappointed by not ever being able to watch it. I don't know exactly when this film was released for USA/Canada audiences, but I'm just glad it finally happened (and I'll be picking this up in addition to my region 4 disc, just for convenience purposes!)For those of you who don't know, Hal Hartley's TRUST is an absolute gem of independent filmmaking. This is a story where you care about EVERY character in the film, as the character development is ridiculously in-depth.I don't want to ruin any of the story for you... if you're on this page, you know about the film, or you were curious enough to research it.In short, the film is laugh-out-loud funny, absolutely dark, DRY, sarcastic, and quick-witted. You absolutely care about the two main characters, and feel sympathy, or empathy, for all of the others. The music's great, the plot is simple but brilliant, and it pokes fun (in a good way) at less intelligent people (such as Maria's boyfriend, or Maria herself). As mentioned above-- the main thing with this film is GREAT character development. In some scenes, this development is way short, and in others, it is deep. But you definitely get a solid understanding of every single character in the movie, and their quirks and/or sadistic behavior.I first found out about this film from a book about good movies, released in 1995, called "Video's Best" by Mark Saturn (available here on Amazon). I rented Trust from the video store back in 1999 and absolutely fell in love with it. Bought it used on VHS years and years back. I would say it is in my top 10 films of all-time, and I am a HUGE movie buff. Huge.So yeah... if you're here because you like indie film, and/or are familiar with Hal Hartley's genius, don't hesitate to pick this up. And if you're here because you just heard about it, and being one of the early films of the late, great Adrienne Shelly, again.... don't hesitate to pick it up. You won't regret it.
summary: One of the best indie films ever made. Hal Hartley RULES.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Trust is Hartley's second feature film and is definitely one my favorites along with Unbelievable Truth, Simple Men, Henry Fool, Flirt, and Book of Life. Adrienne Shelly does a wonderful job as an angst-ridden slacker generation type. As far as Hartley's fare goes, Trust is not a huge departure, it has the usual offbeat humor, realism beneath the surface, interesting use of language, and reminds me maybe of a light-hearted version of Godard. Godard comes to mind anyway. If you like a comedy with some substance, I would recommend this one. Donovan's character carries a grenade, what more can one ask for. If you already like Hartley, Trust is a must, and if you haven't seen any, it's not a bad representation of his style of filmmaking. Trust is a must.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you like John Waters films (particularly "Female Trouble" and "Pink Flamingos") but were disappointed that they didn't quite clear the hurdle to being funny, then "Trust" is for you."Trust" is the follow-on to "The Unbelievable Truth," and features many of the same actors and themes. "The Unbelevable Truth," however, is a screwball romantic comedy, while "Trust" is flat-out black humor. If you're planning to watch both, watch "The Unbelievable Truth" first.I spent the first half of "Trust" laughing, but wondering whether Hal Hartley intended it to be funny. By the end, it becomes clear that he did; this is one very funny film.

reviewText: The whiz bang script, the bittersweet comedy mixed in with the tension the characters brought out of each other - 'We all affect each other in one way or another by simply being in each other's lives!' I can still remember the movie after seeing it 3 times more than 10 years ago! This is another advantage of living outside the US, you get these gems on DVD which for some unknown reason prevent them from being released in the US! One can take advantage of the two markets! Incidentally most DVD players sold in Australia are ZONE FREE! So guys, you might want to take the effort and find the codes to make your DVD players ZONE FREE!

reviewText: I don't like all of Hal Harley's films, but this one really struck me as quite good.  It is a very orignal and creative tragi-comedy and has all the makings of and Indie-classic.  The performances are hilarious, even though  they look quite stale, but then I think that was the idea.  Martin Donovan  is a great actor in all of Hartley's films, and his Matthew character is  incredibly unpredictable, which makes him one of the best screen characters  I've ever seen.

reviewText: Hal Hartley's simple, brilliant masterpiece.  Martin Donovan should have won an oscar for his performance as Matthew Slaughter.  All the characters are written to perfection, and they complement each other perfectly.  The  film is as sad as it is hilarious (there are some 50 lines of dialogue that  are worth quoting here).  Matthew Slaughter's character is made all the  more real by the ending.  As an "empiricist" who doesn't believe  in love, he can only understand what it is (love) once things turn in the  wrong direction for him.  The love between him and Maria Coughlin (Adrienne  Shelly) is not one of those stuffy Hollywood romances, but a simple trust  and understanding between two individuals (admiration, respect, trust equal  love!).  Further complicating matters between them are their downright  sinister parents; Matthew's father beats him, while Maria's mother blames  her for the death of her father.  Simple, intricate, funny, sad, and filled  with nuggets of wisdom, this film ranks up there with "Psycho,"  "Wizard of Oz," "2001" and "Persona" as one  of the crowing achievements of cinema, and unfortunately so very few of you  out there have seen it.
summary: One of the five best films ever made!

reviewText: The female lead in this story is adorable, and the male protagonist plays with an intesity that makes you care about him.  However, the main story line relies on abortion as a casual decision with no consequences - some people may like this attitude and others may be offended.  The rating on this movie can be high or low depending on how you react to this non-advertised story line.  The final scene with the hand grenade is riviting, but when our protagonist get taken away in a police car at the end staring with a half smile to the female lead, which is the end of the movie, one has to wonder - what was that all about?
summary: Casual abortion supporters will like this

reviewText: Strangely, at the time I write this, the DVD is not available in USA. Perhaps the added publicity given to Adrienne Shelley's acting career after her brutal murder will cause this to be rectified quickly.Shelley and Donovan had hipness and chemistry and a great style. It's a minimalist film, but it lingers with you.Watching Hal Hartley's Trust for the second time 15 years later is exhilarating and somewhat disappointing. The characters are contrived and overintellectualized, and the conflict between parent and child here doesn't ring true (it seems to have the usual bitterness of college sophomores). Also the gestures and dialogue are stagy and slightly pretentious. Never mind that; you're missing the point. The film is not aiming at realism; it's aiming at conveying the emotional turbulence of young adult struggling to break free from the orbit of their parents.Plot and incident flow naturally and often end up in unexpected places. There's lots of surprises, many of them comic. The film is about throwing characters together and watching how they react. The moment where the girl messes up the kitchen makes you wonder, how will the father react? The dialogue (reminiscient of Stoppard or Mamet) is curt and enigmatic and challenging. And always entertaining. People are learning from one another and changing..possibly improving. The movie Trust is less about plot than a certain attitude toward life--how much trust should we place in family, friends, peers? People don't have secrets or histories; they have metaphysical complaints and frustrated dreams. Martin Donovan and Adrienne Shelly are not only young charismatic actors, they act and react with subtlety and focus. Yet both have chemistry with one another and manage to sustain this intensity without going too far (Kudos to Mr. Hartley for not aimingfor sympathy or making motives too transparent). Donovan seems adept at playing characters about to boil under, but manage to hold it in (He's at his best in the film Surviving Desire,).Adrienne, that moment when you put on your glasses at the end was a great cinematic moment. Hopeful, assertive and maybe even cocky. Your fans will always have that moment to remember you by.If you liked Trust, you'd also enjoy: Hartley's Surviving Desire (although it's more arty), Jill Sprecher's 13 Conversations about One Thing and her earlier film, Clockwatchers).

reviewText: Back in the days when I was ignorant enough to shell out hard earned (or at least well faked) money for pay movie channels, I was bumbling around the "dial" and ran into the second half of Trust.Later, I made a point of finding the next showing and watched and taped it.I was blown away.  The discourse was uniquely deadpan and honest at the same time.  The acting was fabulous.  Martin Donovan promptly became one of the few actors, and the only actor from North America, whose work is required viewing.  I have a somewhat longer list of actresses, but being an unrepentant auteurist, required films are almost always based on director.After seeing Trust, Hal Hartley was lodged firmly in the mandatory list.  The relationship between Maria and Matthew managed to be both realistic and stylized at the same time.  Not an easy combination to pull off.  They talk to each other, rarely look at each other, and yet the connection is palpable.  The film is deeply compassionate.  The dialogue is like a sort of music, especially in its rhythms, its pauses.  The supporting character roles, especially Maria's father are painted precisely with deft strokes.Trust is one of my favorite Hartley films.  Flirt is the only film of his I have found disappointing, Simple Men and The Book of Life are my favorites.  I loved The Unbelievable Truth.  I seem to have liked No Such Thing more than most other Hartley fans and Amateur slightly less, although I did like it.Trust really should be on DVD and, although several Hartley films have just been released on DVD Trust does not seem to be scheduled yet.  Tsk tsk.  Wait for the DVD.
summary: Oh what luck, and from such an unexpected source

reviewText: This is Hal Hartleys second full movie and it is a step down from his first. The visuals are blah and seemed washed out. The soundtrack is more cheap Casio minimalism which gets pretty anoying. At times it feels a bit like the after school specials that used to exist on t.v. - movies which delt with adolescent topics. However, the lead actors are good and there are a few good lines.If you are not a super Hartley fan I would skip this film and pick instead "Simple Men" or "The unbeleivable truth." Most of the plot points are repeated in one or the other of those films anyway.

reviewText: Is this a dark comedy?  Is this a dark romance?  A drama?  The only thing I know for sure is when I discovered it on IFC fifteen plus years ago (you know...when IFC was actually a channel devoted to independent film unlike the abomination it has become), it completely blew me away and filled my heart.  It's been on my top ten movies list ever since.We have what isn't really a love story ("I respect and admire you", says Matthew Slaughter) between a man and a pregnant 17-year old girl (by the school quarterback, not Slaughter).  She starts the movie as a snotty brash teen who thinks she has the world figured out.  She meets Matthew after being kicked out of the house.  They don't exactly click in terms of love, but WOW do they click emotionally.  They're exactly what each other needs at this point in their lives.  By the end of the film, she's done a LOT of growing up.  Surrounding them is his abusive father and her dysfunctional mother and sister.  Mom, in particular, is an incredibly memorable character.The dialogue is short, simple, and to the point.  The acting is monotone, almost deadpan.  The shooting is unconventional, with conversation going on between parties who aren't even in the shot.  It's completely ridiculous, and yet it's perfect.  It's absolutely perfect.The Blu-ray release isn't exactly reference level.  The picture is pretty soft, probably DNR'd heavily.  The image looks like it was largely shot through a blue filter, which may indeed be the case.  The mono soundtrack can be poppy and unevenly balanced.  But I don't care.  I can't believe it's taken this long to get to DVD, let alone Blu-ray.  This fills a HUGE hole in my collection.
